case_name: Messrs. Associated Clothiers Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 969 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 969 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 5, 1963 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 3 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 5 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 3 of 1958.

facts.text: Ms. Phelps Company Ltd. registered as private limited company on September 30, 1939 to carry on business of Clothiers and Tailors.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. M s. Phelps Company Ltd. was registered as a private limited companypany on September 30, 1939 to carry on the business of Clothiers and Tailors.

facts.text: On March 21, 1952, name of the Company altered to Messrs Associated Clothiers Ltd. under s. 114 of Indian Companies Act, 1913.

anchor.surface_text: On March 21, 1952 under an order made under s. 11 4  of the Indian Companies Act, 1913, the name of the Company was altered to Messrs Associated Clothiers Ltd.

facts.text: On March 21, 1952, Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. incorporated.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day a companypany styled Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. was incorporated.

facts.text: By written agreement dated March 21, 1952, appellant Company agreed to transfer assets and liabilities to Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. for shares Rs. 12,30,000, cash Rs. 23,291/10/5, and taking over liabilities Rs. 6,05,601/6.

anchor.surface_text: By a written agreement also of the same date the appellant Company agreed to transfer its assets and liabilities to Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. in companysideration of allotment of shares of the value of Rs. 12,30,000/of Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. and Rs 23,291/10/5 payable in cash, and Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. taking over liabilities of the appellant Company of the aggregate amount of Rs. 6,05,601/-/6.

facts.text: Appellant Company purported to transfer seven items of property, including building at Connaught Place, New Delhi, valued at Rs. 2,24,673.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the agreement the appellant Company purported to transfer seven items of property described in the Schedules annexed to the deed one of the properties so agreed to be transferred was described in the second scheduled building at Connaught Place, New Delhi, valued at Rs. 2,24,673/-.

facts.text: No deed of conveyance executed in pursuance of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: No deed of companyveyance was executed in pursuance of the agreement.

facts.text: On July 1, 1952, Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. took over possession of the properties on common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, companymon ground that on July 1, 1952, Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. took over possession of the properties agreed to be sold.

facts.text: Original cost of the building Rs. 97,258, written down value Rs. 57,011.

anchor.surface_text: The original companyt of the building described in the second schedule was Rs. 97,258/- and the written down value of the building after deducting depreciation allowed from time to time in the records of the Income-tax Officer was Rs. 57,011/-.

facts.text: In balance sheet of appellant Company dated March 31, 1953, building valued at Rs. 2,24,673.

anchor.surface_text: In the balance sheet of the appellant Company dated March 31, 1953 the building was valued at Rs. 2,24,673/- the price for which it was agreed to be sold.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed for assessment year 1952-53, brought to tax difference between original cost and written down value as deemed profit under second proviso to s.10(2)(vii) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment for the account year 1952-53 the Income-tax Officer, Companies, District IV, Calcutta, brought to tax the difference between the original companyt and the written down value of the building on the date of the transfer as deemed profit of the appellant Company under the second proviso to s. 10 2  vii  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held no profit, sale in substance to self, relying on CIT v. Sir Homi Mehta's Executors.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Appellate Tribunal it was companytended that the sale of assets to the appellant Company was in substance to self and on that account numberprofit had resulted to the Company and the amount sought to be brought to tax was number liable to be included in the Companys profit. The Tribunal relying upon the decision of the Bombay High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Sir Homi Mehtas Executors 1  upheld that companytention.

facts.text: Question referred to Calcutta High Court: Whether Tribunal right in holding sum of Rs. 40,247 not deemed profit under s.10(2)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta the following question was referred to the High Court of Calcutta Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of rupees forty thousand two hundred and forty seven companyld number be deemed to be profits of the assessee companypany under second proviso to, s. 10 2  vii  of the Indian Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under s.66A of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court, with certificate under s. 66A 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, this appeal is preferred.

facts.text: High Court held two distinct corporations existed, transfer was a sale, not to self.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the principle of the decisions in Sir Homi Mehtas Executors case   and in Rogers Co. v. Commissoner of Income-tax, Bombay City 11 2 , did number apply to the facts of the present case, since at all material times there were in existence two companyporations which were distinct and the transfer by one companyporation of its assets to another cannot be deemed to be a transfer to self that the transaction by which the appellant Company transferred its assets to Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. was a transaction of sale,

facts.text: Two companies continued to exist side by side for many years after transfer.

anchor.surface_text: and since the two companypanies companytinued to exist side by side for many years after the appellant Company had transferred its assets to Messrs Phelps Co. Ltd., two different Companies which carried on business simultaneously companyld number be regarded as one entity.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no evidence before Tribunal that appellant Company carried on business after transfer.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel urged that the observations made by the High Court that Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. and the appellant Company companytinued to exist side by side as two separate limited Companies and carried on business simultaneously for, more than ten years is borne out by numberevidence on the record. This criticism has force. The High Court in a reference under s. 66 1  or  2  is bound to proceed on the findings recorded by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal it has numberpower to admit on record additional evidence,

facts.text: All assets and liabilities of appellant Company transferred to Phelps Co. Ltd. as per Tribunal statement.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company also submitted that the Tribunal was in error in observing that the appellant Company had transferred all its assets and liabilities to the new Company. But in the statement of the case which is based upon the judgment of the Tribunal, there is a clear recital -that all the assets and liabilities of the appellant Company were transferred to Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd.

Ltd. is in the form of shares to the appellant Company, but unless there is evidence that the market value of the shares was less than their face value, the claim made by the appellant Company must fail.

holdings.text: The High Court in a reference under s. 66(1) or (2) is bound to proceed on the findings recorded by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and has no power to admit additional evidence not placed before the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel urged that the observations made by the High Court that Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. and the appellant Company continued to exist side by side as two separate limited Companies and carried on business simultaneously for, more than ten years is borne out by noevidence on the record. This criticism has force. The High Court in a reference under s. 66 1  or  2  is bound to proceed on the findings recorded by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal it has nopower to admit on record additional evidence,

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court exceeded jurisdiction under s.66 by considering extra-record evidence of continued business; must confine to Tribunal findings.

holdings.text: There is no evidence before the Tribunal or finding that the appellant Company carried on business after transferring its assets.

anchor.surface_text: as the High Court did, and to consider that additional evidence which was not placed before the Tribunal. We must therefore proceed on the view that there is noevidence before the Tribunal and nofinding of the Tribunal that after transferring its assets the appellant Company carried on business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of High Court error; proceed solely on Tribunal record lacking such evidence.

holdings.text: All assets and liabilities of the appellant Company were transferred to Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. as stated in the Tribunal's statement of the case, which must be accepted absent objection.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Company also submitted that the Tribunal was in error in observing that the appellant Company had transferred all its assets and liabilities to the new Company. But in the statement of the case which is based upon the judgment of the Tribunal, there is a clear recital -that all the assets and liabilities of the appellant Company were transferred to Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statement of case based on Tribunal judgment binding; preamble recital does not indicate retention of assets; no prior objection.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether in tax cases courts may ignore corporate personality and treat shareholder interest as decisive of business ownership.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether in determining liability of an assessee to pay income-tax it is open to the court to ignore the corporate personality of a Company and to fix upon the ownership of the business as decisive, there has been some difference of opinion. [...] It is unnecessary for the purpose of this case to express any final opinion on the question, whether in taxing cases it is open to the assessing authority to ignore the corporate personality of a company

holdings.reasoning_summary: General question obiter as facts involve company-to-company transfer, not individuals-to-company readjustment.

holdings.text: The agreement constituted a transaction of sale in a commercial sense between two distinct companies, attracting the second proviso to s.10(2)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: Here is a case in which the assets of one company have been sold to another. The question to which attention must be directed is whether there was by the agreement, a transaction of sale in a commercial sense.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinct companies; real transfer for consideration unlike individual readjustments; analogous to Chittoor Motor (company to partnership sale); possession transferred July 1, 1952; no conveyance needed.

holdings.text: Agreed specific values in the schedules constitute sale price for s.10(2)(vii); no need for separate market value evidence unless disproved by assessee.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on assessee to show values untrue; no such attempt; applies even to shares unless market value proved less than face.

holdings.text: The transfer was not a slump sale as specific values were allocated to individual properties in the schedules.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Doughty (no itemized valuation); here schedules provide separate values, enabling computation under proviso.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was not right in holding that Rs.40,247 could not be deemed profits under second proviso to s.10(2)(vii); it is taxable.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of rupees forty thousand two hundred and forty seven could not be deemed to be profits of the assessee company under second proviso to, s. 10(2)(vii) of the Indian Income-tax Act ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects self-sale, veil-lifting, substance over form, no value evidence, slump sale arguments; real inter-company sale with specified values exceeding WDV.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel urged that the observations made by the High Court that Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. and the appellant Company continued to exist side by side as two separate limited Companies and carried on business simultaneously for, more than ten years is borne out by noevidence on the record. This criticism has force. The High Court in a reference under s. 66 1  or  2  is bound to proceed on the findings recorded by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal it has nopower to admit on record additional evidence,

Substantially the whole of the companysideration paid by Messrs. Phelps Co. Ltd. is in the form of shares to the appellant Company, but unless there is evidence that the market value of the shares was less than their face value, the claim made by the appellant Company must fail. The burden of proving that the companysideration for sale of the property was less than what it purports to be under the agreement of sale lay upon the Company and since numberattempt was made to prove that fact, the question cannot be raised for the first time in this Court.
